title: Post With Code
text:
Lets work some code into the blog and test it.

# check functions
print("hello world!")

hello world!



# test math
2+2

4



import warnings 
warnings.filterwarnings("ignore", category=UserWarning, module="palmerpenguins")
from palmerpenguins import load_penguins
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np

penguins_df = load_penguins()
penguins_cleaned_df = penguins_df.dropna()

species_counts = penguins_cleaned_df['species'].value_counts()

Show Matplotlib Charts

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

plot = plt.figure()
plot.set_figwidth(6)
plot.set_figheight(3)

plt.bar(species_counts.index, species_counts.values)









plot.savefig("matplotlib_bar.png")

title: blog to follow my learnings
text:
I’m spinning up a Quarto‑powered blog—running it locally, publishing it online, and using it as a living notebook for everything I’m learning across machine learning, data science, AI, and agentic systems. Think of it as a public lab book: part documentation, part exploration, part “let’s see what happens when I push this button.”
I’m stepping in with curiosity, a stack of experiments, and zero certainty about where this path leads. Which is exactly the point.

title: blog to follow my learnings
text: This repository does not accept pull requests (PRs). All pull requests will be closed.

title: Coffee Blog
text:
The idea is also to keep it light – have a break and post something interesting that I stumble upon.
One piece of trivia is that it took me four tries to finally render this online.

















It’s not a dare, it’s just a great choice.









Dec 26, 2025

title: Welcome To My Blog
text: Wish me luck. I’m setting up a Quarto-powered blog, running it locally, and publishing it online. I’ll use it to document what I’m learning as I work through ML, data science, AI, and agents. The image below from Quarto sums it up well: I’m ready to get started and curious about where this goes.
